title: Ask Clay: How did those snails get into Arizona canals?
content:
Today’s question: 

I hope you can help me solve a mystery. For the past couple of months, as I've walked the Crosscut Canal banks between 64th Street and 68th Street, I've noticed large snails (1-2 inches in diameter) on the canal sides. I've never noticed them in the past. Do you happen to know why they are in the canal? 

There are all sorts of creatures living in the Salt River Project canals. Most of them aren’t really supposed to be there, and some can be especially troublesome. 

There are a number of snails and mussels in the canals and most are invasive species. They got into the canals mostly because people have dumped them from ponds or aquariums. There are island apple snails, which are about the size of a golf ball. 

My favorite is the Chinese mystery snail because that’s a cool name for a snail. I’m not sure why it is a mystery, but there you have it. It also is about the size of a golf ball. It first appeared in the canals in 2005. 

And there are red-rim melania, a snail first found in the canals in 1995. The especially troublesome quagga mussel has been moving through the state’s waterways, including the SRP and Central Arizona Project canals for several years. They are very small and can clog water intakes. 

All this is why SRP periodically drains and dredges stretches of the canals, after wrangling the fish to safety. You know how some portions of the canals are covered with small shells? Those are clams — Asian clams, I think — that have been dredged from the canals and dumped on the banks.
